qas.question: What holds the records of the death of Jesus?
What part of the Bible references the death of Jesus?
How many times did Jesus predict his own death?
What part of Jesus' life is detailed in these gospels?

answers.text: Jesus' arrest, trial, crucifixion, burial, and accounts of resurrection

qas.question: How detailed is the description of Jesus' death?
What part of the Bible was written later than the Old Testament?
How many scholars did it take to translate the New Testament?
How quickly were scholars able to interpret and translate the Bible?
What do scholars have to overcome when meeting bias about discussing Jesus?
How did scholars treat the Bible when trying to accurately translate it?

context: The earliest detailed accounts of the death of Jesus are contained in the <a0_0>four canonical gospels<a0_0/>. There are other, more implicit references in the <a1_0><b5_0>New Testament<b5_0/> epistles<a1_0/>. In the synoptic gospels, Jesus predicts his death in <a2_0>three<a2_0/> separate episodes. All four Gospels conclude with an extended narrative of <a3_0>Jesus' arrest, trial, crucifixion, burial, and accounts of resurrection<a3_0/>. In each Gospel these <b6_0>five<b6_0/> events in the life of Jesus are treated <b9_0>with more intense detail<b9_0/> than any other portion of that Gospel's <b8_0>narrative<b8_0/>. Scholars note that the reader receives an almost <a4_0><b7_0>hour-by-hour<b7_0/> account<a4_0/> of what is happening.:p.91
